Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Design of Active Composites Enabled by 3D Printing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports research in establishing a design methodology for 3D printed active composites. In these materials constituents interact such that an object made of the composite alters its shape upon an external stimulus, such as a temperature change. With a 3D printing process composites with complex internal layouts can be manufactured. The composite is printed as an initially flat sheet which takes on a 3D shape after thermo-mechanical treatment, and deforms into yet another 3D shape upon activation. 3D printed active composites open the door for new solutions to a broad class of engineering problems in healthcare, biomedical, aerospace, and automotive applications. For example, active composites would enable novel soft surgical robots whose initial shape is suited for insertion into the human body and which are then deployed into a desired shape to assist a surgical procedure. Currently there exist no tools for systematically designing these composites. This research involves several disciplines, including mathematics, mechanics, and computer science. This setting will provide a stimulating environment for students who will participate in this project and broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research. Outreach activities will bring the excitement of 3D printing into K-12 classrooms.

The active composite consists of glassy polymers embedded in an elastomeric matrix. The temperature dependence of the mechanical properties of glassy polymers creates a shape polymer effect. The properties of the polymer phases depend on complex processing conditions during 3D printing. The constitutive response will be described as temperature-dependent and anisotropic nonlinear viscoelastic. Experiments on the thermomechanical response will support the constitutive model development. The design methodology will integrate the nonlinear material models into a multi-material topology optimization approach. The location and shape of glassy polymer inclusions as well as parameters defining the programming loads will be optimized simultaneously. Consequently, the composite assumes a set of target shapes due to thermo-mechanical treatment and upon activation. The geometry of the material interfaces will be described by a level set method. The response of the printed composite objects will be predicted by a generalized formulation of the extended finite element method. To account for manufacturing constraints, such as limitations in printer resolution, constraints for controlling the minimum feature size in 3D material layouts will be developed. The optimization problem will be solved by a gradient-based algorithm, computing the gradients of objective and design constrains by the adjoint method. Experiments will be employed for validation of the design methodology.

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Today’s 3D polymer printers can deposit multiple materials with distinctly different properties within one printing step. These properties, such as the elastic modulus, typically depend on temperature, and cause the materials to exhibit a shape memory behavior. After undergoing a thermo-mechanical training cycle, a shape memory polymer deforms in response to a temperature change.

Another type of material that undergoes large deformation in response to an external stimulus are elastomeric gels. These materials are typically used by 3D printers as sacrificial support materials that are removed after the printing process. In this project, we studied using the ability of these materials to swell when exposed to a solvent. Thus, the polymeric gels are not removed after the printing process but used to enhance the material system.

This project focused on Printed Active Composites (PACs) where materials that deform due to an external stimulus are combined with passive materials. PACs deform from a printed flat configuration into a desired spatially curved shape upon activation. To achieve a particular shape, the spatial arrangement of active and passive constituents needs to be carefully designed, accounting for the complex constitutive response and large deformations. 

In this project, a rigorous optimization framework for the design of 3D printed, multi-material, active composites was created. A level set approach was studied to spatially arranges active materials within an inactive matrix. The response of the composite was predicted by the eXtended Finite Element Method (XFEM), incorporating constitutive models for shape memory polymers and elastomeric gels. These models were developed in collaboration with Georgia Institute of Technology.

Robustness of the computational methods and numerical algorithms of the optimization framework is of pivot importance for the applicability of the design methodology to practical problems. Novel schemes for stabilizing the XFEM formulation of elastomeric gels were created and studied. New schemes for regularizing the level set optimization problem were researched to promote the smooth evolution of geometry in the optimization process and to control the minimum feature size.

Optimized designs were fabricated and experimentally characterized. The results show a good agreement between numerical prediction and measured response of the PACs. The project benefitted from tight domestic and international collaborations and provided a unique learning experience for graduate and undergraduate students.


Last Modified: 12/03/2019
Modified by: Kurt K Maute

Images (1 of )
  • Design of a Printed Active Composite using Shape Memory Polymers: An active phase - dark gray in (a) - is embedded in a passive matrix - light gray in (a). The geometry of the active phase was designed such that upon activation the plate undergoes a parabolic deformation.
    Kurt Maute
    Kurt K Maute
    Design of a Printed Active Composite
  • Design of a Printed Active Composite using eigenstrains generated by printing process: (a) Numerical simulation of actuated design with eigenstrains represented by red color. (b) and (c) show printed sample in initial and actuated states.
    Kurt Maute
    Public Domain
    Kurt K Maute
    Design using printed eigenstrains
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Today’s 3D polymer printers can deposit multiple materials with distinctly different properties within one printing step. These properties, such as the elastic modulus, typically depend on temperature, and cause the materials to exhibit a shape memory behavior. After undergoing a thermo-mechanical training cycle, a shape memory polymer deforms in response to a temperature change. Another type of material that undergoes large deformation in response to an external stimulus are elastomeric gels. These materials are typically used by 3D printers as sacrificial support materials that are removed after the printing process. In this project, we studied using the ability of these materials to swell when exposed to a solvent. Thus, the polymeric gels are not removed after the printing process but used to enhance the material system. This project focused on Printed Active Composites (PACs) where materials that deform due to an external stimulus are combined with passive materials. PACs deform from a printed flat configuration into a desired spatially curved shape upon activation. To achieve a particular shape, the spatial arrangement of active and passive constituents needs to be carefully designed, accounting for the complex constitutive response and large deformations. A level set approach was studied to spatially arranges active materials within an inactive matrix. The response of the composite was predicted by the eXtended Finite Element Method (XFEM), incorporating constitutive models for shape memory polymers and elastomeric gels. Optimized designs were fabricated and experimentally characterized. The results show a good agreement between numerical prediction and measured response of the PACs. The project benefitted from tight domestic and international collaborations and provided a unique learning experience for graduate and undergraduate students.
